{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3527582,"name":"Eric (319)","username":"EKM_319","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ekm_319/{size}/230932_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-15T00:12:26.099Z","cooked":"

Good evening Chief Delphi!

Our students this week have been fighting code migrating to using Phoenix v6 APIs for setting up subsystems, and they ran into some behavior that I haven’t yet put my finger on.

The issue they encountered was that setting a motor to follow another.

At first, the students were using motor.set(percentOutputValue) instead of the seemingly proper motor.setControl( )

However, upon doing so, the behavior (seeing only the lead motor move) was still occurring.

We tried changing which motor was the leader and which motor was the follower, and changing it such that the appropriate lead motor was instructed to move, and found that when our 'new leader / previous follower '(CANID:14) motor moved, the ‘previous lead motor / new follower’ (CANID:13) would follow it with the appropriate inversion.

I did some digging with the debugger, and both ways the motor.setControl() are returning a status of ‘OK’ so I was wondering if anyone else has seen this behavior.

I was wondering if we had misunderstood the logic of the follower API… but we double checked against the docs

Phoenix 6

Control Requests

Phoenix 6 provides an extensive list of flexible control modes through the use of strongly-typed control requests. Using Control Requests:,, v5,, Java C++,, v6,, Java C++,,,, Follower Motors:,, v5,...

I’ve provided the subsystem with some comments (marked by EKM) I’d love it if somebody could cross check and comment if we’re missing something obvious.

I’m personally wondering if there’s something that we missed about applying TalonFXConfiguration to the motor(s) ; and we’ll continue to experiment tomorrow. But any assistance is appreciated!

gist.github.com

https://gist.github.com/ilandprnce/a9bf9f94cb6a166d06fb643e71f520c9

ElevatorIOKraken.java
package frc.robot.subsystems.elevator;

import com.ctre.phoenix6.BaseStatusSignal;
import com.ctre.phoenix6.StatusSignal;
import com.ctre.phoenix6.configs.TalonFXConfiguration;
import com.ctre.phoenix6.controls.DutyCycleOut;
import com.ctre.phoenix6.controls.Follower;
import com.ctre.phoenix6.hardware.TalonFX;
import com.ctre.phoenix6.signals.InvertedValue;
import com.ctre.phoenix6.signals.NeutralModeValue;
This file has been truncated. show original

To restate, our motors are moving in a way that ‘works’ but I’m hoping to understand what we did wrong so that we can ‘do it right’. We did also crosscheck against other team’s public code, and it seems were on the right track… but just missing something simple likely.

github.com

Mechanical-Advantage/RobotCode2025Public/blob/68ccced508b7f13249eb837ad5dc42355e359a1f/src/main/java/org/littletonrobotics/frc2025/subsystems/superstructure/elevator/ElevatorIOTalonFX.java#L61


      
    
          
  1. 
          
  2. private final TorqueCurrentFOC torqueCurrentRequest =
    3. 
          
  3.     new TorqueCurrentFOC(0.0).withUpdateFreqHz(0.0);
    4. 
          
  4. private final PositionTorqueCurrentFOC positionTorqueCurrentRequest =
    5. 
          
  5.     new PositionTorqueCurrentFOC(0.0).withUpdateFreqHz(0.0);
    6. 
          
  6. private final VoltageOut voltageRequest = new VoltageOut(0.0).withUpdateFreqHz(0.0);
    7. 
          
  7. 
          
  8. public ElevatorIOTalonFX() {
    9. 
          
  9.   talon = new TalonFX(13, "*");
    10. 
          
  10.   followerTalon = new TalonFX(14, "*");
    11. 
          
  11.   followerTalon.setControl(new Follower(talon.getDeviceID(), true));
    12. 
          
  12. 
          
  13.   // Configure motor
    14. 
          
  14.   config.MotorOutput.NeutralMode = NeutralModeValue.Brake;
    15. 
          
  15.   config.Slot0 = new Slot0Configs().withKP(0).withKI(0).withKD(0);
    16. 
          
  16.   config.Feedback.SensorToMechanismRatio = reduction;
    17. 
          
  17.   config.TorqueCurrent.PeakForwardTorqueCurrent = 80.0;
    18. 
          
  18.   config.TorqueCurrent.PeakReverseTorqueCurrent = -80.0;
    19. 
          
  19.   config.CurrentLimits.StatorCurrentLimit = 80.0;
    20. 
          
  20.   config.CurrentLimits.StatorCurrentLimitEnable = true;
    21. 
          
  21.   config.MotorOutput.Inverted = InvertedValue.Clockwise_Positive;
    22.

Solved :

There was an issue having enabled can bus optimizations on the leader. Such that the follower wouldn’t follow
